b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:37): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8.pdf
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:37): thanks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:39): holy god
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: one would think that somebody would have transcribed it by now
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:41): Fortunately Google lets you view the PDF file as HTML
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:41): indeed. I guess the IETF is very serious about maintaining original formatting
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:41): "Networ-k l'iorki.ng Group Request foT. Comnerrt: 8"
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (17:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Why would you guess that, rather than guessing that nobody has cared enough to bother transcribing it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:45): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: because they also care about ASCII formatting to printable pages with form feeds and hard line breaks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:52): to me, the whole IETF culture in general seems radically different from W3C
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (17:53): seems like IETF folks and browser people and others involved at W3C are coming from very different set of experiences and assumptions
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:56): the views on the text/* content types is certainly very different
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Heh. Been reading www-archive then?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:06): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: yes
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:13): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: any clues as to why the HTML5 spec defines content models for <ul> and <ol> as zero or more <li>s (instead of one or more)?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:13): HTML4 defined it as one or more
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:13): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: It gets annoying when programmatically outputting data, or having an empty list to work on via script, etc.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:14): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: my understanding is that this way doesn't require authoring tools to insert bogus placeholders
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:14): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: also what a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 said
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:14): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 : I see -- thanks
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (18:16): encountered that problem himself, wanting to write <ul>[% FOR i IN items %]<li>...[% END %]</ul> but then discovering it's invalid HTML4 in some edge cases
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (18:18): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Any clues as to why the HTML4 (or earlier) spec defined it as one or more?
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (18:20): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: Any clues as to why the HTML4 (or earlier) spec defined it as one or more? :-)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:20): I'd suspect because at the time they were less aware of use cases of people authoring docs whose contents were meant to be dynamically updated when they were served
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:22): That use case is still often missed by people
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:23): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:23): fwiw, I've found it's also one of the problems with restrictions on id/xml:id values in source
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: How so?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: People na?Øvely generating them?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:28): It isn't hard to generate conformant @id values

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:30): no, sometimes you want to put placeholder content into an xml:id attribute value and then have some post-processing done on it to resolve it into a real id value
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (18:30): defined what as one or more?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:30): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: li
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:30): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: <li> in <ul> and <ol>
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:30): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Can't you use data-* for that? :P
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (18:30): well, in the tech doc SGML culture, an empty list was a bug to be fixed
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (18:31): so you have to do: if items <ul> for i in items </ul> end if

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (18:33): IETF culture radically different? gee... it doesn't seem that way to me, a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 . there's more variation between groups within W3C and within IETF than between the orgs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:34): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: I will agree with you about variation between W3C groups
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:34): I guess I should have qualified it by saying the W3C groups I'm involved with
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:34): those that focus on client-side technologies, browser technologies
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:34): as opposed to.. whatever else
